Dated the 18th and received 19th i£ay, 1945. 'h) /f Your telegram No. 303 dated May 5th. Trucial Coast wheat figures. 2. Following is extract from LI.B.S.C., Baghdad telegram No. 8 dated May 15th. Begins: “Irucial Coast stocks have increased during April by 700 tons approximately the amount delivered during month. Are they also purchasing ? If wheat is being bought please indicate quantities, country of origin and price.” Ends. 3. Even despite the fact that deliveries during April were 1290 tons and not 700 tons as stated by LI.E.S.C. consumption works out at only 600 tons as against quota of 820 tons. 4. Galloway, Bagh Shaikh, Shiraz- 526. Dated the 19th July 1945. . ‘l Aa i 2 . Your telegram No. T/137 dated the 18th July. Trucial Coasts consumption of cereals per montn is 1230 (half 2460) tons. As will be apparent from my telegram I\io. 510 ated the 14th July it had approximately two months supjjly on 1st July. . 1 5 3. Bahrain’s consumption is 1000 (half 2000) tons per month. To cereal stock figures in my telegram 498^ ^ dated 9th July please add 740 (half 1480) tons rice now taken over by Bahrain Government and 800 (half 1600) tons wheat received on l£th July fron U.K.C.C. stocks and it will be apparent Bahrain has stock to last for two months and three weeks as from 1st July. Regret tnerefore I see no repeat no good reason for taking rice from Trucial Coast. ^ should be glad if I could be informed amount of next consignment of wheat fDD Trucial Coast and when it will arrive. [N.B .—This is an ORIGINAL message tent by AIR MAIL which provides a means of communication more expeditious than the ordinary mail and is cheaper than the telegraph. Difabtmixt, EXPRESS LETTER [N.B .—This is an ORIGINAL MESSAGE, sent by post to save telegraphic expense and undue use of the wires, but intended to be treated, on receipt, with the same expedition as if it had been telegraphed. To save time and formalities it is worded and signed as if it had been so despatched,} From Political, Bahrain* To The Political Agent, Bahrain, Camp Shiraz* No. 3455 - 29/20* Bahrain, Bated the 29th August 19&5. Reference Residency Express Letter No* C/190 of 18th August* 2* Figures are in conformande with form submitted monthly for last 18 months* Wheat and barley are imported into U.K.C.C. stocks - not into Bahrain Government stocks* Imports have therefore always been shown as NIL* Orders are subsequently given for the release of wheat/barley from U*K*C*C* stocks to the Bahrain Government* These figures, also, have never been shown as imports* If you agree, they may be shown in future as such* 3* 800 tons of wheat imported to U.K.C.C* stocks was therefore not shown in monthly stock report* Export of 603£ tons wheat and 290 tons barley re present releases from U.K.C.C. stocks to Saudi Arabia and have s. 6. MFP—601 S& P—(M- 820>—23- 7-36—300,000. /always/6*••• t always been shown thus In the past* I suggest that in future these figures are omitted because stock reports refer to Bahrain stocks and not to those of U*K*C*C. rg 7 4. Rice imported in July was 90 tons and figure in our telegram No* 595 of 12th August is correct* Figure of 740 tons of rice taken over by Bahrain Government and reported in para 3 of our telegram No* 526 of 19th July represents quantity taken over by Bahrain Government from stocks previously imported and i reported in monthly stock reports* l*e* 215 tons in March 4 tons in April 240 tons in May 350 tons in June Total 809 tons* Out of 809 tons imported in March-June (inclusive), Bahrain Government took over 650 tons plus 90 tons imported in July equals 740 tons* I suggest that rice imported into Bahrain is only shown in monthly stock report if and when the Bahrain Government take it over* To summarise, my suggestions are that, as ^ 6 . P monthly stock report shows Bahrain Government stocks only, a) Imports should Include releases from U*K*C*C. f J A stocks* b) Exports should not show re-exports to Baud! Arabia -which are from U.K.C*C* and Bahrain Government stocks* u tTl ^ / *? <n. aC-je c) Import of rice should only show tlwawg taken over by Bahrain Government*rrm ”) e ?» X <r The prescribed form used in the past has been adhered to and figures in that form were correct and were checked by me* The misunderstanding appears to be due to the fact that the stock reports did not show the true positionv } !t> v Telegram G.T.C. B, Thisi» an ORIGINAL MESSAGE, tent by poll to taw. telegraphic expense and undue use of the wires, hut intended to he treated, on receipt, with the same expedition as if it had been telegraphed 1 o save time and formalities it is worded and signed as if it had been so despatched,] POLITICAL AGKNCY, BAHRAIN. From Political, Bahrain. To Gallovray, Bagh Shaikh, Shiraz. 3666 • 29/20. Bahrain, Dated the 9th September . Your Express Letter No. C/190 of the 18th August 1945. Monthly stock reports. P 2. Imports of wheat and barley have been shown as Nil in the last twelve monthly reports. Reason is that monthly report^ does not show TJ.K.C.C. stocks (c.f. Your telegram No.1176 of the 13th May 1944) and all imports are on U.K.C.C. account subsequentlv being released to Bahrain Government account. Quantities taken over in Bahrain by the Government from U.K.C.C. stocks are now being shown as imports in column 1. 3 # Rice imported in July was 90 tons and figure in our ,,, ft telegram No. 595 of 12th August is correct. Figure of 740 tons of rice taken over by Bahrain Govern ment and reported in para 3 of our telegram No. 526 of 19th July represents quantity taken over by Bahrain Government from stocks previously imported and reported in monthly stock reports. /i.e. s. 6. MFP—601 S&P—(M-820)—23-7-3&—300,000.ite# 215 tons in March 4 tons In April 240 tons in May 350 tons in June Total 809 tons* Out of 809 tons imported in March/June (inclusive) f Bahrain, Gov eminent took over 650 tons plus 90 tons imported in July equals 740 tons* 4* Exports of wheat and barley for Saudi Arabia from U.K*C*C* stocks in Bahrain have bean included in column 2 in the past (c»f* stutem^nts for December» February| March* June and July)* I agree this procedure / is wrong as they are not from Bahrain Government stocks nor are they re-exports for inclusion in column 5* They will therefore be excluded altogether in future. , . \ h 5. Is column 5 (re-exports to Saudi Arabia) in the form proscribed in your memorandum No* C/66* dated the 15th March 1943 required? If not, may it be omitted in future? In practice it is nev^r used except for small quantities of sugar, tea and piecegoods* Sd/- C.J.FELLY. POLITICAL AGENT, BAUBAIN. POLITICAL AGENCY| BAHRAIN. The 15th September 1945 To The Director of Customs Bahrain. MEMORANDUM Will you please furnish on the 1st of each English monfch commencing from the 1st of October 1945, in the form indicated below, figures in tons of rice, wheat, flour, sugar, tea and cotton piecegoods for the previous months- (1) Quantity imported (2) Quantity exported (3) Existing stocks (4) Period of sufficiency in months (5) Quantity re-exported to Saudi Arabia. 2. a) Cereals taken over from U.K.C.C. stocks in Bahrain should be shown as importe in column (l) above. b) Exports to Saudi Arabia from U.K.C.C. stool in Bahrain should not be shown in column (2) or (5). c) The period of sufficiency should be calculated on the quota basis of 670 tnns of wheat and 330 tons of barley /millet per month^ &ut please note that tha follov/ing reductions of cereals have been made during July, August and September only against rice imports of 740 tnns:- Wheat @ 170 tons per month for each July August and September = 510 ton$ and barley § 77 tons per month for each July, August and September = 230 tons. The period of sufficiency for September therefore should be calculated on the basis that 670 minus 170 = 330 minus 7^ = and 740/3 = 500 tons of wheat, 253 tens of barley 247 tons of rice are required per month for internal consumption. , for POLITICAL AG ANT, iiAhRAIN KMS —'9 GOVERNMENT OF INDIA, Depabtucnt, EXPRESS LETTER [IV. B. —This is an ORIGINAL MESSAGR!, sent by post to save telegraphic expense and undue use of the wires, but intended to be treated, on receipt, with the same expedition as {f it had been telegraphed. To save time and formalities it is worded and signed as if it had been so despatched,] From Political, Bahrain* . To. Political Resident, Bushire. Not 4167 - 89/20* Bahrain, Baled the 3rd October 254 5. ✓ w Your memorandum No*C/66 dated Marfih 15th, 1943* September. 1 # Bahrain Government. Wheat 1449 80* 1030 1$ months nil Barley nil nil 3 - nil Millet nil nil 699 2 months nil Flour 28 nil 18 - nil Rice 240 nil 455 2 months nil Sugar 88 25 272 2 months 45 Tea nil 17 63 2 months nil Piecegoods ♦To Qatar. 67 nil ' nil Notei- Period of sufficiency for wheat and millet has been calculated on the monthly quota figure of 670 and 330 tons respectively as no rice imports habe as yet been set off against the quota for October onwards. 2. Figures for Trucial Coast follow. Sd/- C.J.PELLY. POLITICAL AGENT, BAHRAIN. Attested ‘ s. 6.Assistant Political Agent, MFP—1198 S&P—(M-2302)—22-2-38—300,000. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: ‘File 29/20 ii BAHRAIN & TRUCIAL COAST STOCK POSITION AND STATEMENT OF BAHRAIN IMPORTS, EXPORTS AND RE-EXPORTS OF CERTAIN FOODSTUFFS’

physicalDescription.extent: Files papers are arranged more or less chronologically.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 210; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-194; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence. Condition: the back file cover is lacking.

mods.abstract: This is a correspondence file about the importation of essential food commodities and cotton piece goods from India to Bahrain and the Trucial Coast ports of Dubai and Sharjah, under the quota system and the export licensing restrictions imposed by the Government of India during the Second World War (1939-1945), due to wartime shortages. The file contains the correspondence of the Political Agent, Bahrain with the Political Officer for the Trucial Coast and the Residency Agent, both Sharjah; the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire; the Director of Customs and Port Officer for the Government of Bahrain and the shipping agent Gray, Mackenzie & Company Limited, Bahrain. They exchange information about existing stock levels of imported quota foodstuffs such as rice, wheat, flour, tea, coffee and sugar, as well as cotton piece goods for clothing. They also discuss arrangements for the timely shipment and distribution of new supplies, for local consumption in Bahrain and the Trucial Coast shaikhdoms, as well as re-exportation to Saudi Arabia in exchange for other essential commodities in short supply. Included in the file are numerous lists that were regularly compiled and circulated by the Director of Customs and Port Officer, Bahrain; the Political Officer for the Trucial Coast and the Residency Agent, both Sharjah and also Gray, Mackenzie & Company Limited, acting as agent for the United Kingdom Commercial Corporation (Iraq) Limited. These lists show existing levels of essential food stocks in Bahrain and the Trucial Coast shaikhdoms, how long these were expected to last and details about shipments of new supplies from India, to maintain or replenish exhausted stocks.

name.namePart: Gray, Mackenzie and Company Limited, shipping agents
Director of Customs and Port Officer
